    > >One of the disadvantages to this is that it makes it a 
    > little harder to
    > have
    > >that solitary project that will be responsible to run 
    > all tests, not
    > >impossible by any means, it just takes more doing.
    > 
    > I'm not sure I understand your point. Can you explain?

A difference of style here.  We have all of our individual tests compiled
into some TestSuite.  We then include all of those test suites into the
AllTests package in the AllTests project.  Our buildSuite() method becomes
just a few lines of code, referencing all of the other project suites (whose
buildSuite() methods are also short and sweet, including only the classes
for that package).  But it seems you have stepped around this by
programmatically loading every test case in the workspace.  Do you also load
the JUnit test cases (e.g. MoneyTest)?

    > I  use the VAJ toolapi to extract automatically all tests 
    > to be run (see
    > below code. Not perfect code, but it's TSTTCPW). They can 
    > easily be packaged
    > in another JAR if needed (with ant for example).

How do you do this outside of VAJ using the Tools API?

    > collectTests() will find every TestCase subclass in the 
    > workspace. I have a
    > ant script that loads the latest release stuff before 
    > running this.

When you say "loads", you mean it loads into VAJ?

    > Those running the tests still need the code to be tested 
    > anyway. One other
    > point for this way of having tests in the same 
    > package/project that I didn't
    > mention is that it's very easy to keep versions in sync 
    > (tests & code). If
    > you have two projects, you can end up runnning old tests 
    > on newer classes,
    > etc..

We don't encounter this problem since the tests projects map one-to-one with
the production code projects, as well as the packages within them.  I guess
I dont' quite comprehend how this could happen.

Thanks for your thoughts!

-Jason
